Melvindale Saint Joseph South Bend Toledo
New Carlisle Intersection Study, TO#TCC-1-D, Final Tech Memo
The intersection of SR 235, Linden Avenue and Church Street is located on the south end of the City of New
Carlisle, in western Clark County. While crash data has not indicated any safety problems, the City of New
Carlisle has expressed concerns that there are safety issues at this intersection. This study will assist the
Clark County-Springfield Transportation Coordinating Committee (CCSTCC) and the City of New Carlisle to
evaluate the potential realignment of this intersection.
The intersection of SR 235, Linden Avenue and Church Street is a four-legged intersection with SR 235
travelling southwest and northeast. Linden Avenue intersects from the west while Church Street intersects
from the north at 30 degrees. SR 235 (Main Street) continues northeast into downtown New Carlisle. The
northbound approach on SR 235 includes a 200 foot left-turn lane. The three other approaches are single
lane approaches. Linden Avenue and Church Street are both local streets with posted speed limits of 25
MPH. SR 235 is an urban minor arterial with a posted speed limit of
35 MPH. The posted speed limit is reduced to 25 MPH immediately
north of the intersection. DLZ conducted a field visit at the
SR 235 is 40 feet wide and provides two-way traffic with one lane in
each direction and a northbound left-turn lane. There is on-street
parking approximately 250 feet south of the intersection in the
northbound direction, but based on field observation, this parking
is not utilized. Church Street is also 40 feet wide with one lane in
each direction. There is on-street parking on both sides of the
street. Throughout the day, on-street parking near the intersection
Currently, the existing intersection is unsignalized with stop control on Linden Avenue and Church Street and
free-flow traffic along SR 235. There are stop signs present at the intersection, but the stop bars are not
marked. A curb ramp is present at each corner of the intersection, however, none of them are ADA
compliant and there are no marked crosswalks.
Approximately 1000 feet south of the intersection, there is a horizontal curve on SR 235. The speed limit
south of the curve is 55 MPH. There is a posted 35 MPH speed limit sign and an electronic “Your Speed” sign
for northbound vehicles located on the curve. During field observations, it was noted that many vehicles did
not reduce their speeds from the 55 MPH to 35 MPH while approaching the intersection from the south.
Approximately 700 feet north of the study intersection, SR 235 curves to the left.
Based on the ODOT Location and Design Manual, Section 401.3, the intersection angle of two crossroads
should be between 70 degrees to 90 degrees. The current configuration does not meet this standard, with
Church Street intersecting SR 235 at approximately 30 degrees.
Based on field observations, there are multiple sight distance issues at the intersection of SR 235, Linden
Avenue, and Church Street. First, the angle at which Church Street intersects SR 235 forces southbound
drivers on Church Street to either approach the intersection at an angle, or to turn their heads approximately
150 degrees to the left in order to see traffic travelling southbound on SR 235. This makes it difficult to see
traffic in both directions. Additionally, the Domino’s Pizza
parking lot is located on the corner between SR 235 and Church
Street. Based on observation, the lot was consistently full
between 3:00 PM and 6:00 PM. When the lot is occupied,
vehicles on Church Street and Linden Avenue cannot see vehicles
coming around the curve travelling southbound on SR 235.
Likewise, vehicles travelling southbound on SR 235 cannot see
vehicles stopped on Church Street and Linden Avenue. Another
sight distance issue is caused by the house on the south side of
Linden Avenue. If an eastbound vehicle is stopped at the stop
sign on Linden Avenue, the house obstructs any view of the
traffic south of the intersection. In order to see past the house,
drivers would pull up past the stop sign.
During the field observation, it was noted that several vehicles
travelling southbound on Church Street and turning right onto SR
235 would tend to pull into the intersection blocking Linden
Avenue while waiting for a gap in traffic on SR 235. Additionally,
a majority of the vehicles in the northbound left-turn lane would turn onto Church Street. Knowing this,
southbound drivers stopped at the stop sign on Church Street would proceed into the intersection assuming
the left-turning vehicles were turning onto Church Street and not Linden Avenue. This could lead to a
potential conflict if the driver would turn onto Linden Avenue.
The observation notes and photos from this visit are given in Appendix A. See Exhibit 1 for a condition
DLZ performed an 8-hour turning movement count (7 – 9 am, 11 am – 2 pm, and 3 -6 pm) at the intersection
of SR 235, Linden Avenue and Church Street in May 2014. With direction from the Clark County Engineer’s
Office, an annual growth rate of one percent (1%) was used to calculate 20-year projected traffic volumes at
the intersection. These counts were used for a signal warrant analysis and capacity analysis. See Appendix B
Based on a previous study completed within the downtown corridor, pedestrians crossing the roadway not
within crosswalks have been an issue in the area. During the traffic count, DLZ took note of any pedestrian
crossings. Between 3:45PM and 4:45PM, there were seven (7) pedestrians crossing Church Street mid block
(not at the corners or within marked crosswalks). Four (4) of these pedestrian crossings were to and from
the Domino’s Pizza on the corner of the intersection. The other three (3) occurred about 500 feet north of
the intersection. A diagram of the pedestrian crossings is included in Appendix B.
DLZ acquired crash data from the past five years using ODOT’s GCAT program. There were five (5) crashes
that were reported at the intersection from year 2010 through January 2014, with no crashes occurring in
Of the five (5) crashes, two (2) resulted in injury while the other three (3) were property damage only. Two
(2) of the crashes were rear-end crashes, both occurring at the stop sign (no stop bar marked) on the
southbound Church Street approach. One of the rear-end crashes occurred under icy road conditions, but it
was not stated that the road conditions played a factor in the collision. In both rear-end crash situations, a
driver pulled out from the stop sign and stopped partially in the intersection to wait for traffic when they
Two (2) crashes were sideswipe crashes. One of these sideswipe crashes occurred when a driver travelling
southbound on Church failed to yield while turning right onto SR 235 and came into contact with a driver
The other crash that occurred at this intersection was an injury head-on collision, where a driver making a
left-turn from the northbound SR 235 left-turn lane failed to yield to a vehicle travelling southbound on SR
Tables 1a-1g summarize the crash statistics at SR 235, Linden Avenue and Church Street. See Appendix C for
crash data and Exhibit 2 for a crash diagram at the intersection.

text.b: Tables 1a-1g: Crash Statistics at SR 235 & Linden Avenue & Church Street

page.text: The ODOT Traffic Engineering Manual (TEM) and the Ohio Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices
(OMUTCD), which provide criteria and guidance for the installation of stop signs and traffic signals, were
utilized in order to perform an analysis for the intersection of SR 235, Linden Avenue and Church Street using
The OMUTCD provides nine (9) individual signal warrants, where one or more should meet the minimum
requirements in order to justify a traffic signal installation. For this analysis, the first three warrants were
analyzed because these are the volume warrants. Additionally, the pedestrian volumes warrant (Warrant #4)
and the crash experience warrant (Warrant #7) were analyzed. Warrants # 5 (School Crossing), #6
(Coordinated Signal), #8 (Roadway Network), and #9 (Intersection Near a Grade Crossing) were not
Based on ODOT roadway functional classifications, SR 235 is classified as an urban minor arterial while Linden
Avenue and Church Street are both classified as urban local streets. In accordance with the ODOT TEM, the
count data gathered was adjusted based on seasonal adjustment factors as well as minor street right-turn
In order to perform a signal warrant analysis using PC Warrants, Church Street and Linden Avenue were
percentile speed was assumed to be less than 40 MPH because the
posted speed limit on SR 235 is 35 MPH at the intersection. However, based on 2010 Census data, the City of
New Carlisle has a population of about 6,000. Therefore, based on the OMUTCD, the intersection was taken
to be within a built-up community, and thus the 70 percent volumes were used in the signal warrant analysis.
Table 2 summarizes the signal warrant analysis. The complete results of the signal warrant analysis are
The intersection at SR 235, Linden Avenue, and Church Street did not meet any of the volume warrants. The
intersection met zero (0) hours of the required eight (8) hours of Warrant #1, and zero (0) hours of the
required four (4) hours of Warrant #2. The peak hour volumes also did not exceed the minimums for any
The OMUTCD states two criteria for the pedestrian volume warrant, each requiring a minimum pedestrian
volume crossing the major street in order to justify a signal installation. The four-hour volumes criteria
requires a minimum of 75 pedestrians per hour while the peak-hour volume criteria requires a minimum of
93 pedestrians per hour. At the intersection of SR 235, Linden Avenue, and Church Street, there were no
pedestrians crossing SR 235, and at most, five (5) pedestrians crossing Linden Avenue or Church Street.
These volumes did not meet the required minimum, and therefore Warrant #4 was not met.
The crash experience warrant requires there to be five (5) correctible crashes reported within a 12-month
period. Based on the crash data gathered, only two (2) correctible crashes occurred between 2010 and 2014.
Capacity is the volume of traffic that can pass through a roadway facility in a given amount of time
(vehicles/hour). The concept of Level of Service (LOS) is a qualitative measure of the operation of traffic flow.
LOS considers such factors as speed, travel time, freedom to maneuver, traffic interruptions, driver
inconvenience, safety, and delay. For different transportation facilities, the LOS is based on different
Intersections are measured for average control delay in seconds per vehicle. Control delay includes initial
deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped delay, and final deceleration delay. The delay
measurement for vehicles at a signalized intersection is a combination of driver discomfort, driver

text.b: Table 3: LOS Criteria for Unsignalized Intersections

page.text: The LOS rating system as described in the 2010 Highway Capacity Manual gives a value of A through F to each
type of roadway facility representing best to worst traffic conditions. When designing roadway
improvements, it is desirable to accommodate peak hour volumes at a LOS C or D. Table 3 summarizes the
Levels of Service for unsignalized intersections.
DLZ used the collected traffic data in order to perform a capacity analysis (year 2014) using Synchro 8.0. Per
the Clark County Engineer’s Office, a 1% per year growth rate was used to project 20-year traffic volumes.
These projected volumes were used to perform a future capacity analysis for year 2034.
In order to perform a capacity analysis using Synchro, Church Street and Linden Avenue were combined into
one approach. Existing peak hour analysis shows that the intersection at SR 235, Linden Avenue, and Church
Street currently operates at LOS B in both the AM and PM peak hours. During the AM peak hour, the
intersection delay is 11.5 seconds and during the PM peak hour, the intersection delay is 13.4 seconds.
Using 20-year projected traffic volumes (year 2034), the intersection will operate at LOS B in the AM peak
hour with 12.8 seconds of delay and at LOS C during the PM peak hour with 16.5 seconds of delay.
Table 4 summarizes the unsignalized Levels of Service and Delays for the existing and projected volumes in
year 2014 and year 2034. See Appendix E for the complete Synchro results.

text.b: Table 4: SR 235, Linden Avenue, & Church Street unsignalized LOS

page.text: *Worst movement Level of Service and Delay shown for
Based on the signal warrant analysis and the capacity analysis, the current conditions at the intersection of
SR 235, Linden Avenue, and Church Street do not warrant the installation of a traffic signal. While an analysis
of the crash data does not show many crashes at this intersection, there are sight-distance issues and
geometric issues due to the angles of Church Street and Linden Avenue as they intersection SR 235, which
creates an environment with high potential for crashes and other safety issues, particularly as traffic
increases at this intersection. The following alternatives provide ideas for enhanced safety at the

i.b: Alternative #1 – Realign Church Street & Cul-de-sac Linden Avenue

page.text: Many of the potential safety issues and concerns are caused by the current configuration of the intersection.
To improve safety, it is recommended to realign Church Street to intersect SR 235 at 90° to form a T-
intersection. This relocation is required to meet the crossroad alignment requirement in the ODOT L&D
Manual, which requires an intersection angle of 70 degrees to 90 degrees. This would require the acquisition
of the property on the corner of the intersection between Church Street and SR 235 (Domino’s Pizza). This
would increase the sight distance for drivers on the Church Street approach. This realignment would also
alleviate drivers on Church Street from having to look behind them to see traffic travelling southbound on SR
235 at the intersection. Separating Church Street and Linden Avenue would also eliminate any potential
conflicts caused by turning vehicles and vehicles pulling into the intersection while waiting for a gap in traffic
See Exhibit 3 for conceptual drawing of Alternative 1.
However, based on guidelines from the ODOT Location and Design Manual, the realignment
recommendation would require a design exception if federally funded. Using the required degree of
curvature and radius would call for the acquisition of at least two additional properties. Based on
engineering judgment, a design exception would be allowed for a smaller radius because the curve is
approaching a stop-controlled intersection, meaning drivers would be
slowing down as they travel along the curve.
With a realignment of Church Street, additional signing should be
installed. A Stop Ahead (W3-1) sign should be placed along the curve to
warn drivers of the upcoming intersection. A stop sign (R1-1) and a street
name sign should be placed at the intersection and a stop bar should be
marked. Additionally, based on ODOT guidelines, future traffic volumes
along SR 235 require a northbound left-turn lane of 286 feet (See
Appendix F for turn lane calculations). This turn lane should be properly
marked and a lane control sign should be installed.
Along with the realignment of Church Street, Alternative 1 includes closing
off Linden Avenue with a cul-de-sac. This would eliminate access to Linden
Avenue to and from SR 235, but would also eliminate any turning movement
conflicts out of Linden Avenue. It would also eliminate any delay caused by
vehicles turning into and out of Linden Avenue. The cul-de-sac
recommendation would allow drivers, including single-unit trucks, to turn
around, and would have a minimal impact on existing right-of-way. With a
cul-de-sac configuration, a No Outlet sign (W14-2) would be needed on
Linden Avenue in order to inform drivers that there is no access to SR 235. There were 8 vehicles during the
AM peak hour and 25 vehicles during the PM peak hour going to and from Linden Avenue from SR 235. These
vehicles would need to be diverted to the north.
o Improves sight distance from Church Street
o Eliminates potential conflicts between Church Street and Linden Avenue
o T-intersection decreases the angle at which drivers on Church Street are required to turn to
o Requires the acquisition of right-of-way on the corner between Church Street and SR 235
o No access into or out of Linden Avenue from SR 235
o Vehicles would be diverted to the north in order to access neighborhood

i.b: Alternative #2 – Realign Church Street & Full-access to Linden Avenue w/ Right-in, Left-in, & Right-out from

page.text: Alternative 2 includes the same realignment of Church Street as recommended in Alternative 1. Along with
the realignment, a channelized right-turn would restrict movements on the
Linden Avenue approach to a right-turn only. Drivers wanting to turn left would
be diverted to other north/south streets. This would eliminate potential conflicts
due to left-turning vehicles from Linden Avenue. Traffic would have full access to
Linden Avenue from SR 235. This configuration would require additional signing
including lane control signs (R3-H8ba) and a no left-turn sign (R3-2).
See Exhibit 4 for a conceptual drawing of Alternative 2.
With full access to Linden Avenue, a 125 foot northbound left-turn lane would be
required (based on 20-year projected volumes) on SR 235 to Linden Avenue. This
would only allow for a 110 foot northbound left-turn lane at Church Street, where
the ODOT required turn lane length is 286 feet. Based on field observations, the
queue length for northbound left-turning vehicles reached up to 8-10 vehicles at a
time during the afternoon peak hour. Having turn lanes at both Linden Avenue
and Church Street could cause potential safety issues with SR 235 northbound
drivers not knowing if the vehicle in front of them will be making a left-turn at Linden Avenue or Church
o Improves sight distance from Church Street
o Eliminates potential conflicts between Church Street and Linden Avenue
o T-intersection decreases the angle at which drivers on Church Street are required to turn to
o Full access to Linden Avenue from SR 235
o Requires the acquisition of right-of-way on the corner between Church Street and SR 235
o Restricts left-turns from Linden Avenue
o Left-turn lane at Church Street does not meet ODOT requirements
o Southbound vehicles slowing to turning onto Linden Avenue would cause slight delays in

i.b: Alternative #3 – Realign Church Street & Restrict access to Linden Avenue w/ Right-out from Linden Avenue

page.text: Alternative 3 also includes the same realignment of Church Street, but restricts the turning movements to
and from Linden Avenue to a right-out only. This would allow for an adequate storage lane length for the
northbound left-turning vehicles at Church Street. This would also
eliminate any delay south of Church Street due to turning vehicles on SR
Utilizing this configuration would also require additional signing including
Do Not Enter signs (R5-1) and a no left-turn to Linden Avenue sign.
See Exhibit 5 for a conceptual drawing of Alternative 3.
o Improves sight distance from Church Street
o Eliminates potential conflicts between Church Street and Linden Avenue
o T-intersection decreases the angle at which drivers on Church Street are required to turn to
o Eliminates delay due to southbound traffic turning to Linden Avenue
o Allows for adequate turn-lane length at Church Street
o Requires the acquisition of right-of-way on the corner between Church Street and SR 235
o Restricts left-turns from Linden Avenue
o Eliminates access to Linden Avenue from SR 235

i.b: Alternative #4 – Slight Realignment of Church Street & Restrict access to Linden Avenue w/ Right-out from

page.text: Alternative 4 is similar to Alternative 3, restricting the turning movements to and from Linden Avenue to a
right-out only. Again, this would allow for an adequate storage lane length for the northbound left-turning
vehicles at Church Street. This would also eliminate any delay south of Church Street due to turning vehicles
However, the realignment of Church Street is altered to fit the existing right-of-way.
from the ODOT Location and Design Manual, the realignment recommendation would require a design
exception if federally funded. Using the required degree of curvature and radius would call for the
acquisition of at least two additional properties. Based on engineering judgment, a design exception would
be allowed for a smaller radius because the curve is approaching a stop-controlled intersection, meaning
drivers would be slowing down as they travel along the curve.
Using the existing right-of-way, this realignment would allow for southbound drivers on Church Street to
intersect SR 235 at about a 70 degree angle, which complies with ODOT L&D standard. This would increase
the sight distance for drivers on the Church Street approach. This realignment would also alleviate drivers on
Church Street from having to look behind them to see traffic travelling southbound on SR 235 at the
intersection. Separating Church Street and Linden Avenue would also eliminate any potential conflicts
caused by turning vehicles and vehicles pulling into the intersection while waiting for a gap in traffic on SR
Utilizing this configuration would require similar signage as described from Alternative 3.
See Exhibit 6 for a conceptual drawing of Alternative 4.
o Improves sight distance from Church Street
o Eliminates potential conflicts between Church Street and Linden Avenue
o Angle of intersection decreases the angle at which drivers on Church Street are required to
turn to look for oncoming traffic
o Eliminates delay due to southbound traffic turning to Linden Avenue
o Allows for adequate turn-lane length at Church Street
o Utilizes existing right-of-way (No property acquisition required)
o Angle of Church Street and SR 235 intersection is acceptable but less than the desired 90
o Restricts left-turns from Linden Avenue
o Eliminates access to Linden Avenue from SR 235

i.b: Alternative #5 – Mini-Roundabout at Church Street & Restricted access to Linden Avenue w/ Right-out from

page.text: Alternative 5 also restricts movement at Linden Avenue to a right-out only. This would also eliminate any
delay south of Church Street due to turning vehicles on SR 235. Unlike alternatives 1-4, Alternative 5 utilizes
a mini-roundabout at the intersection of SR 235 and Church Street. Constructing a mini-roundabout at this
intersection would improve safety by increasing sight-distance, eliminating potential conflicts between
Church Street and Linden Avenue, and reducing crash severity.
Similar to the other alternatives, a realignment of Church Street would be required in order for the proper
geometrics of a mini-roundabout. This realignment would require a design exception based on guidelines
from the ODOT Location and Design Manual, if federally funded. This would also require a partial acquisition
of the corner property (Domino’s). Based on engineering judgment, a full-take would not be required;
however, parking at this establishment would be greatly impacted.
A mini-roundabout with an inscribed circle diameter (ICD) of 72 feet would require that traffic on each leg be
reduced to 30 MPH. Additionally, an ICD of 72 feet can typically support a single-unit truck or bus. Based on
observations, heavy vehicles including semi-trailer trucks and heavy farm equipment would be required to
See Exhibit 7 for a conceptual drawing of Alternative 5.
o Improves sight distance from Church Street
o Eliminates potential conflicts between Church Street and Linden Avenue
o Reduces crash severity at intersection
o Eliminates delay due to traffic turning south of Church Street
o Significantly decreases pedestrian crossing distance
o Requires partial acquisition of right-of-way on the corner between Church Street and SR 235
o Restricts left-turns from Linden Avenue
o Eliminates access to Linden Avenue from SR 235
o Speed reduction required along SR 235
o Heavy vehicles must maneuver small diameter, but central island would be designed to be

i.b: Alternative #6 –Compact Urban Roundabout at Church Street & Restricted access to Linden Avenue w/

page.text: Alternative 6 utilizes a compact urban roundabout. As in Alternative 5, movement at Linden Avenue would
be restricted to a right-out only. Alternative 6 would provide similar benefits as Alternative 5, with improved
safety, but would be designed to accommodate larger design vehicles (with an ICD of 110 feet).
Similar to the other alternatives, a realignment of Church Street would be required in order for the proper
geometrics of an urban roundabout. This realignment would require a design exception based on guidelines
from the ODOT Location and Design Manual, if federally funded. This would also require the acquisition of
See Exhibit 8 for a conceptual drawing of Alternative 6.
o Improves sight distance from Church Street
o Eliminates potential conflicts between Church Street and Linden Avenue
o Reduces crash severity at intersection
o Eliminates delay due to traffic turning south of Church Street
o Significantly decreases pedestrian crossing distance
o Allows for landscaping for the entrance into the downtown corridor
o Requires the acquisition of right-of-way on the corner between Church Street and SR 235
o Restricts left-turns from Linden Avenue
o Eliminates access to Linden Avenue from SR 235
Based on the 20-year projected traffic volumes, a capacity analysis was performed for each alternative. With
Church Street and Linden Avenue separated into two intersections, both would operate at LOS B in both the
AM and PM peak hours for all four stop-control alternatives. A capacity analysis was performed for the two
roundabout alternatives using RODEL. For both alternatives 5 and 6, the mini-roundabout and urban
roundabout would operate at LOS A in both AM and PM peak hours. Tables 5 and 6 summarize the
unsignalized Levels of Service and Delays for each alternative. See Appendix E for complete Synchro and
See Appendix B (Traffic Count Data) for projected traffic distributions corresponding to each alternative.

text.b: Table 5: SR 235 & Church Street unsignalized LOS Summary
Table 6: SR 235 & Linden Avenue unsignalized LOS Summary

page.text: *Worst movement Level of Service and Delay shown for unsignalized intersection.
*Worst movement Level of Service and Delay shown for unsignalized intersection.
From a safety standpoint, a total closure with a cul-de-sac of Linden Avenue would be ideal by eliminating all
turning movements to and from Linden Avenue at this intersection. However, restricting all access to and
from Linden Avenue would not be desirable for residential traffic that would have to be diverted to the
north. Based on turning movement counts, approximately 100 vehicles would be diverted over the 8-hours
By permitting northbound left-turns from SR 235 to Linden Avenue, potential conflicts would be created in
the turn lane. Based on observation and ODOT guidelines, the left-turn lane at Church Street in Alternative 2
would not be long enough to support the left-turning traffic at several times throughout the day. These
vehicles would back up into the left-turn lane at Linden Avenue. Additionally, if a vehicle is stopped in the
turn lane at Linden Avenue, drivers behind them may try to bypass them to get to Church Street. From a
safety standpoint, a single left-turn lane only to Church Street would be ideal. By removing left-turn
movements to Linden Avenue, adequate storage would be given to the left-turn lane at Church Street,
eliminating any potential safety issues in the left-turn lane. Also, by restricting Linden Avenue to a right-out
only, potential conflicts from left-turning movements would be eliminated at Linden Avenue.
Based on observation and analysis, and after evaluating each alternative, Alternative 4, which requires no
